text:
good day!
I want to connect with some applications (specifically, the The Tie). However, their documentation is only available for Kubernetes. Our validator uses Docker Compose. Are there any guides or documentation available for connecting via Docker Compose?

elements.text:
good day!
I want to connect with some applications (specifically, the The Tie). However, their documentation is only available for Kubernetes. Our validator uses Docker Compose. Are there any guides or documentation available for connecting via Docker Compose?

text:
<https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_compose.html#requirements>

With regard to Docker Compose, looking at the `compose.yml` file included in the downloadable release artifacts, it seems the setup is intended to run entirely on a single EC2 instance. However, this makes it difficult to scale the resources launched via Docker Compose.

 In particular, scaling PostgreSQL is not feasible unless it is separated from Docker Compose and replaced with a service like Amazon RDS.

Should components such as validators and participants be built in a way that allows them to scale?

elements.text: With regard to Docker Compose, looking at the

file included in the downloadable release artifacts, it seems the setup is intended to run entirely on a single EC2 instance. However, this makes it difficult to scale the resources launched via Docker Compose.

 In particular, scaling PostgreSQL is not feasible unless it is separated from Docker Compose and replaced with a service like Amazon RDS.

Should components such as validators and participants be built in a way that allows them to scale?

text: I think this is why Kubernetes is recommended. The docker compose is great for running your own private devnet but for production there are a lot of caveats. If going with docker compose, using RDS would be ideal so it can be scaled and backed up easily.

elements.text: I think this is why Kubernetes is recommended. The docker compose is great for running your own private devnet but for production there are a lot of caveats. If going with docker compose, using RDS would be ideal so it can be scaled and backed up easily.

text:
Regarding the major upgrade, after reviewing the documentation, it appears that the transition from `eventId` to `offset` and `nodeId` is intended to apply on a go-forward basis only — can you please confirm?

Specifically, we want to verify that historical transactions (i.e., those that occurred prior to the upgrade) will remain unchanged, and that this adjustment only impacts future data processing.

We're planning a cutover related to chain syncing and want to ensure we align this change appropriately per environment, timed with and following the upgrade rollout.
CC: <@U04RWTP1TA5>
